text.text: How do I access the Aging by Current Payer report?

text: To run the Aging by Current Payer report, you can select the accounting period end date and then either the billed or service date. You can also select the start and end date, and the level of service. To run the report, you can go to the navigation bar, hover over Analytics, and click Reports. Then, scroll down the list and click Activity Summary by Primary Payer.

text.text: What information does the Aging by Current Payer report provide for each current benefit policy?

text: The Aging by Current Payer report provides the following information for each current benefit policy: Current payer name, Revenue adjustments, Revenue adjustment reversal, Profit center, DOS Charges, Charge adjustment, Billed date, Charge reversal, Interest, Balance, Payment, Write off, Payment reversal, Write off reversal, 0-30 days, 31-60 days, 61-120 days, 91-120 days.

text.text: Can I customize the date range for the Aging by Current Payer report?

text: Yes, you can customize the date range for the Aging by Current Payer report. You can select the accounting period end date and then either the billed or service date. You can also select the start and end date, and the level of service.

text.text: What are the different categories included in the report, such as 0-30 days, 31-60 days, etc.?

text: The report also includes the following categories: 121-150 days, 121-180 days, 181+ days.

text.text: How can I interpret the information under each category in the Aging by Current Payer report?

text: The information in each category is grouped by the number of days since the claim was received.

text.text: Are there any specific actions recommended based on the data in this report?

text: The report can be used to monitor any claims that have a balance older than 30, 60, or 90 days. Follow-up specialists can use this information to work overdue claims.

text.text: In what formats can I save or print the Aging by Current Payer report?

text: The Aging by Current Payer report can be saved in XML, CSV, PDF, MHTML, Excel, TIFF, or Word format. It can also be printed.

text.text: How frequently should I run the Aging by Current Payer report?

text: The Aging by Current Payer report can be run anytime to compare net charges against payments and as a tool to determine your company's health. Try running separate reports for several months in a row, and then compare the reports to understand the trajectory of your business and find monthly patterns.

text.text: Can I analyze trends or patterns in payment behavior using this report?

text: The Aging by Current Payer report can be used to monitor any claims that have a balance older than 30, 60, or 90 days. Follow-up specialists can use this information to work overdue claims.

text.text: How does this report contribute to managing accounts receivable efficiently?

text: The Aging by Current Payer report provides information about the current state of your accounts receivable. It includes information such as: Current payer name Revenue adjustments Revenue adjustment reversal Profit center Over 180 days DOS Charges Charge adjustment Billed date Charge reversal Interest Balance Payment Write off Payment reversal Write off reversal 0-30 days Take back 31-60 days Provider level adjustment Refund 61-120 days Payment Refund reversal 91-120 days

text.text: What insights does the Activity Summary by Primary Payer report provide?

text: The Activity Summary by Primary Payer report provides information about charges, allowances, payments, adjustments, write-offs, expected CO-45, and refunds by payer.

text.text: How do I access the Activity Summary by Primary Payer report?

text: To run the Activity Summary by Primary Payer report, you can follow these steps: 1. On the navigation bar, hover over Analytics and click Reports. 2. Scroll down the list and click Activity Summary by Primary Payer.

text.text: What types of information are included in the Activity Summary report?

text: The Activity Summary by Primary Payer report provides information about charges, allowances, payments, adjustments, write-offs, expected CO-45, and refunds by payer.

text.text: Can I filter the report based on the level of service?

text: Yes, you can filter the report based on the level of service. You can select All or one or more levels of service.

text.text: How can I use the Activity Summary by Primary Payer report to evaluate my company's financial health?

text: You can run the Activity Summary by Primary Payer report anytime to compare net charges against payments and as a tool to determine your company's health. You can also try running separate reports for several months in a row, and then compare the reports to understand the trajectory of your business and find monthly patterns.

text.text: Are there any specific metrics or indicators highlighted in the report?

text: The Activity Summary by Primary Payer report can be saved in an XML, CSV, PDF, MHTML, Excel, TIFF, or Word format. It can also be printed.

text.text: How does running this report over several months help in understanding business trajectory?

text: You can also try running separate reports for several months in a row, and then compare the reports to understand the trajectory of your business and find monthly patterns.

text.text: What actions can I take based on the findings from the Activity Summary by Primary Payer report?

text: You can run the Activity Summary by Primary Payer report anytime to compare net charges against payments and as a tool to determine your company's health. You can also try running separate reports for several months in a row, and then compare the reports to understand the trajectory of your business and find monthly patterns.

text.text: Can I export the Activity Summary by Primary Payer report to different file formats?

text: Yes, the Activity Summary by Primary Payer report can be saved in an XML, CSV, PDF, MHTML, Excel, TIFF, or Word format. It can also be printed.

text.text: How frequently should I run the Activity Summary by Primary Payer report to ensure accurate financial analysis?

text: To run the report, you can follow these steps: 1. On the navigation bar, hover over Analytics and click Reports. 2. Scroll down the list and click Activity Summary by Primary Payer. 3. Start and End Date: Pick how far back you want the report to start and the date you want it to end. 4. Level of Service: Click to select All or one or more levels of service. 5. Click View Report.

text.text: What can I know from Activity Summary by Primary Payer?

text: The Activity Summary by Primary Payer report includes information about charges, allowances, payments, adjustments, write-offs, expected CO-45, and refunds by payer.

text.text: How to run the report in Activity Summary by Primary Payer?

text: To run the report, you can follow these steps: 1. On the navigation bar, hover over Analytics and click Reports. 2. Scroll down the list and click Activity Summary by Primary Payer. 3. Start and End Date: Pick how far back you want the report to start and the date you want it to end. 4. Level of Service: Click to select All or one or more levels of service. 5. Click View Report.

text.text: What is the Recommended use of Activity Summary by Primary Payer?

text: The Activity Summary by Primary Payer report can be run anytime to compare net charges against payments and as a tool to determine your company's health. Try running separate reports for several months in a row, and then compare the reports to understand the trajectory of your business and find monthly patterns.
